Jim Gilbert wrote:
> Rich,
> I tend to agree with Alan.  Looking at t=
he front of the guard it does appear to be Edo period and indeterminate sty=
le.  I suspect that what you're seeing in the rim may be the structure of t=
he forge welding brought out by the rust.  It's not unusual to see pronounc=
ed layering in, for example, Akasaka guards that have been badly rusted.  S=
eeing a sharp ridge like that would be unusual for tekkotsu.  Also tekkotsu=
 are usually smoother, darker and more lustrous than the surrounding iron (=
although not always so with Kanayama).
>
> I do however have a Kanayama tsu=
ba that I think is quite old that has a somewhat similar look in the rim.  =
I've never been able to decide how much of the appearance is due to how it =
was made vs. how it might have rusted.  Next time I set up to take macro ph=
otos I'll get some images of the rim for comparison.  The face of that guar=
d also looks quite old and in Kanayama style, though.
>
> Jim
>
>
>
>   Hi =
Alan, it may be a little pitted in the mimi but they are bones, and 
>   to=
o big I think for edo, though not necessarily so I guess.
>
>   Cheer
>
>  =
 Rich
>
>

n poor shape with a pitted mimi.

ork. These are excellent photo's and an invaluable help.

got it and thought it might be Kanayama. There is

ope ) bone in the mimi, and quite a few smaller normal 
>   >   bumpy bones=
. There are also small bones in the hira, running around the 
>   >   mimi.=
 I have not been able to pin the theme either, besides the ginger 
>   >   =
leaves.
